posts.cooked:
EXTREMLYIMPORTANTLY Mentors for FRC Team 4416 Yotam discuss their approach to wiring CANbus using Ethernet cables and parallel CAN bus networks. Key steps involved evaluating existing CAN bus setups, identifying limitations, and exploring solutions. The team decided against traditional CANbus configurations due to issues with CAN signal integrity and reliability. Instead, they focused on combining Ethernet cables with parallel CAN bus topology.  

They designed a Node PCB connecting CAN to up to four devices and transmitting via four twisted pairs in a CAT5e Ethernet cable. A Hub PCB connected multiple subsystems in parallel or series. Testing confirmed successful CAN signal transmission via Ethernet cables. The system proved robust enough to handle CAN-related failures during competitions. Performance metrics showed ~50â€“60% CAN utilization with 21 devices, meeting competition demands. Minor challenges included inflexible Ethernet cables and tight routing in a compact robot design. Overall, the solution effectively addressed CAN communication needs.

link_counts.title: CAN Connector (5 Pack) â€“ CTR Electronics
What Are the Best Practices for a Reliable CAN Bus Setup?

posts.name: Michael Hill
posts.cooked: Iâ€™ve always thought CAN over Ethernet made sense to do. Understandably, the size of the socket is a major turn-off. Cool solution. As far as flexible Ethernet cables go, you can get pretty flexible Ethernet cables. Monoprice sells patch cables in pretty small AWG that might work for this application, though Iâ€™m not sure of the availability in Israel.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: Did you check the weight of all of those cables? Iâ€™m guessing it was substantially more than small green/yellow wires. However, if the reliability increased, it may be worth it.

posts.name: TomerBARZ
posts.cooked: The robot weighed approximately 40 kilograms, which is equivalent to 88 pounds. Therefore, the weight of the cables didn't pose any problem for us.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: sounds interesting how does your solution compare to something like a wago we had the same experience with ctre connectors in 2023 and this year and 2024 we used wago and had zero issues

posts.cooked: I forgot to include it in the thread, but we used it at the 2024 season and experienced frequent disconnections, primarily due to moving parts.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
The compliment sandwich ðŸ˜Š:  
The bread: Iâ€™m glad you had success and reliability with your CAN network this year!  
The meat: The Ethernet cable as a media is fine in my book. Iâ€™m a bit more concerned about your network topology though.  

Because we are dealing with relatively small CAN 2.0 networks this year, this particular wiring worked for you.  

As I understand you: both PDH and Rio with terminating resistors were connected to the hubs and all other devices at various stub lengths to different nodes tied back to the hub.  

CAN relies on the placement of the terminations to work reliably (absorbed reflections and improved signal quality). High-speed transitions cause signal reflections when they reach the end of a stub. These reflections worsen with longer stubs. Constructive and destructive interference with the original signal degrades signal quality until it becomes unreadable by devices.  

Your topology has a very short bus with both terminations at a single or linked hub, and devices are far away on long stubs. These are poor design choices.  

Since weâ€™re using lower-speed CAN and relatively small networks, reflections didnâ€™t degrade signals enough to make devices unreadable. However, adding subsystems could introduce reflections that make the entire bus unreliable. Youâ€™ll run into problems faster with high-speed CAN, especially with the new 2027 control systemâ€”wiring this way will throw errors, leading to potential failures.  

You focused on CAN, improving wiring quality and connections, achieving your goal of no CAN issues this year.  

Redesigning your network can maintain similar results but may remove some benefits of the hub-and-spoke topology. It allows for daisy chaining as a logical or safety fault behavior. Electrically, the bus should be wired with stubs and terminations ensuring predictable and in-spec signal integrity.

posts.name: TomerBARZ
posts.cooked: Thank you for your in-depth comment. We are aware of the potential issues that our CAN system can cause and will keep those in mind when preparing for the next season. Before we committed to this design, we conducted tests on a practice bot using hand-soldered (no PCB connectors) longer wires (over 3m), albeit with fewer CAN devices, to ensure everything would work as expected. As you mentioned, it probably wonâ€™t work on a CANivoreâ€™s CAN-FD or on the new SystemCore. In those cases, weâ€™re less concerned about the parallel CAN bus since we can split different subsystems into separate CAN networks (if I understand correctly). Weâ€™ll need to conduct some more testing in preparation for next year, focusing on more CAN devices and varying stub lengths to see if we can stay within spec or if everything breaks completely.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: Iâ€™m not sure if you are following the concepts I spewed out in the early morning for me. When testing our design, we used hand-soldered longer wires and fewer CAN devices to ensure functionality. This evaluation focuses on build quality rather than CAN Bus topology. As explained earlier, testing such topologies isnâ€™t straightforward due to potential unpredictable failures. Each bus configuration is unique, leading to variable behavior with added nodes, possibly causing sudden and unexpected malfunctions. Even if the system works initially, issues like elevator failures could disconnect numerous devices, potentially rendering the entire bus inoperative. How are you assessing performance? Relying solely on resistance readings (~60Î©) and bus utilization misses critical aspects of signal integrity. While improving focus on build quality has enhanced our yearly performance, itâ€™s crucial to recognize that this topology may introduce long-term issues requiring advanced troubleshooting skills. To achieve more predictable results, investing in standard components like RJ-45 jacks and Ethernet cables for CAN communication could yield better outcomes.

Jwal has developed a method to simplify robot wiring by creating a standard cable for CAN and sensor connections, acknowledging his limited availability for investment.

The SWYFT Cannect Wiring System enables running CAN and 12V power over Ethernet cables, reducing wiring complexity and supporting dual CAN wire pairs for reliability. Priced at $39.99, it features built-in redundancy, eliminating the need for separate CAN and power cables.

This system is compatible with passive Poe, allowing bidirectional data transmission. Designed for Swerve Drivetrains, it streamlines setup, enhances efficiency, and ensures consistent operation by bypassing common wiring challenges.

Additional features include a straightforward installation guide and compatibility across various devices, making it ideal for FIRST robotics competitions.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: I knew this existed and this is the bus topology I would recommend to the OP - long bus, termination on each end, short stubs. Iâ€™m still sympathetic to OPâ€™s configuration although I see a way to make it work for Sensors (analog or digital) directly connected to the RIO/future control system. Thatâ€™s where Iâ€™d need to focus more. Time is limited, and from my College days, I know I have much more to accomplish than time allows; thus, creating a prioritized list and starting with whatâ€™s most important is essential. This task currently sits lower on my life list.

Clean wiring concept! Could be a cool off-season project to test out the short-stub topology on your bot with the same wiring but slight layout modifications to your boards. Excuse my MS paint ECAD. Youâ€™d need to jump the hub if you donâ€™t use all 4 RJ45s, but otherwise, it should be a drop-in replacement.
